metadata.case_name: State Trading Corporation of India Ltd. & Cement Marketing Company of India Ltd. v. State of Mysore & Anr.
metadata.case_number: Original Jurisdiction Petitions Nos. 65 and 66 of 1960

facts.text: Two petitions under Art. 32 seeking writs to quash assessment orders imposing sales tax on cement sales and consequential reliefs.
Assessment orders made on Cement Marketing Company of India Ltd. in respect of sales of cement in 1957-58 as agent of State Trading Corporation of India Ltd.
Disputed sales involved movement of cement from outside State of Mysore into it.
Two assessment orders: sales April 1, 1957 to Sept 30, 1957 under Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1948; Oct 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958 under Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957.
Cement could be purchased only under permit issued by Government naming supplier (Marketing Company) and cement factory outside Mysore.
Purchaser placed order with Marketing Company on receipt of permit; firm contract made subject to permit terms.
Taxing Officer observed contracts did not provide for supplies from particular factory; supplies from outside Mysore for supplier's convenience.
Cement concerned in disputed sales actually moved from another State into Mysore.
Central Sales Tax Act s.3 came into force Jan 5, 1957; whole assessment year 1957-58 after that.

legal_issues.text: Whether the disputed sales occasioned the movement of cement from another State into Mysore within the meaning of s.3(a) Central Sales Tax Act, making them inter-State sales not taxable by State.
Whether movement was result of covenant in or incident of contract of sale.
Whether petitions competent under Art.32 in view of Ujjam Bai decision.

petitioner_arguments.text: Disputed sales were inter-State sales as they occasioned movement of goods from one State to another; State could not tax them.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 286, 269 Constitution; Central Sales Tax Act s.3(a); Constitution Sixth Amendment Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Marketing Company made sales as agent of Trading Corporation; assessment orders void affecting fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f) and 31.

respondent_arguments.text: Movement of cement was not result of covenant in or incident of contract of sale; supplies from outside Mysore only for supplier's convenience.
Petitions incompetent per Ujjam Bai as Taxing Officers had jurisdiction to decide if sale inter-State; error does not offend fundamental rights.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Smt. Ujjam Bai v. State of Uttar Pradesh

court_reasoning.text: Sale occasions movement if result of covenant in or incident of contract of sale per Tata Iron Steel Co.
court_reasoning.key_observation: A sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce if the sale or purchase occasions the movement of goods from one State to another.

court_reasoning.text: Each contract subject to terms of permit which named factory outside Mysore for supply; contracts deemed to contain covenant for supply from outside into Mysore.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sale could only be under permit and on terms contained in it.

court_reasoning.text: Post Sixth Amendment and Central Sales Tax Act, States cannot tax inter-State sales.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State could not impose tax on such sale.

court_reasoning.text: Ujjam Bai distinguishable: Taxing Officer acted without jurisdiction as constitutional prohibition against taxing inter-State sales; could not assume jurisdiction by wrong collateral fact decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If quasi-judicial authority acts without jurisdiction or wrongly assumes jurisdiction by error as to collateral fact, Art.32 petition lies.

holdings.text: Disputed sales were inter-State sales under s.3(a) Central Sales Tax Act as movement resulted from covenant/incident of contract via permit terms.
Assessment orders void; State had no jurisdiction to tax inter-State sales.
Petitions under Art.32 competent as Taxing Officer acted without jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Iron Steel Co. Ltd. v. S.R. Sarkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that sale occasions movement if result of covenant in or incident of contract of sale under s.3(a) Central Sales Tax Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Ujjam Bai v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.32 petition lies if quasi-judicial authority acts without jurisdiction or wrongly assumes by error on collateral fact violating fundamental right.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits States from taxing inter-State sales post amendment; enables Art.32 petitions for fundamental rights enforcement.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines inter-State sale including where sale occasions movement of goods from one State to another; in force during assessment year.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied to sales April 1, 1957 to Sept 30, 1957; assessments quashed.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed 1948 Act from Oct 1, 1957; applied to later sales; assessments quashed.

outcome.summary: Petitions allowed; assessment orders quashed as disputed sales were inter-State sales not taxable by State of Mysore due to constitutional prohibition and Central Sales Tax Act definition.
outcome.relief_granted: Writs to quash assessment orders and prevent levy/collection of tax.

key_quotes.text: "A sale or purchase of goods shall be deemed to take place in the course of inter State trade or commerce if the sale or purchase- (a) occasions the movement of goods from one state to another."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct quote from s.3(a) Central Sales Tax Act central to determining inter-State sale.

key_quotes.text: "the contracts must be deemed to have contained a covenant that the goods would be supplied in Mysore from a place situate outside its borders."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key reasoning why movement was incident of contract due to permit terms.

key_quotes.text: "a State could not impose a tax on such a sale."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on State's lack of jurisdiction post constitutional amendments.
